body: but as I said in chat: though it's deprecated in LaTeX - it's so damn convenient that it still works

When we say MathJax delimiter, do we mean the characters that we use to surround mathjax expressions in markdown? Because I'm pretty used to using $, and I think that's been our advice for a while, so it might irritate quite a few people if it broke.
A big -1 to deprecating $ to delimit math.  I'm with Thomas.
While the use of $$ is deprecated and [ should be used instead, are you sure $ is also deprecated ?

See video discussion - http://youtu.be/UUjTAq8cCcs?t=57m

Parsing the dollar symbols as math delimiters becomes incredibly complicated if the user wants to write a document containing dollar symbols in is/her text.  Using the Notebook as-is to write a financial document is not feasible (you can't escape the dollar symbols.)

EDIT: Direct link
@jdfreder - if you get the chance, can we post a more directed link (with the specific time)

> When we say MathJax delimiter, do we mean the characters that we use to surround mathjax expressions in markdown? 

Yes, there are loads of problems with it. It's really not sustainable.

I feel like supporting `\[ \]` is the right way forward, but what about the fact that `$` and `$$` still work in LaTeX - and a lot of people still use them. I'm ok with saying it's deprecated, but I'm not ok with completely disabling it within the next decade ;)
It was a mistake to support it, but maybe deprecating it is not feasible.  Deprecation without removal of support doesn't actually alleviate any problems, I think.

Direct link-
http://youtu.be/UUjTAq8cCcs?t=57m

Thank you for the video link.

Do you still plan to support both \[ ... \] and \( ... \), too ?
That would be nice and make ist easier to simple copy+paste from latex.

@juhasch almost. Since we are mixing markdown and latex - the single backslash escapes are currently used to type those characters literally, and the math escapes are `\\[` ... `\\]` and `\\(`...`\\)`. This isn't ideal, though.

I think the \\[ and \\] is awkward, and maybe unnecessary.  I don't think $$ ...  $$ is problematic (but I'm not a financial person). 

The % sign is not used as a comment, so I don't see the need to support $..$.  But I would not replace with a 3 symbol string.   Something like $| ... |$, perhaps -- some 2 symbol combo unlikely to be used elsewhere.  Most important is that  inline should be easy to type (probably why $ first used -- it is a shortcut in almost every language, it seems).

About the dollar thing -- come on -- asking for it to be removed is so so totally one-sided. How about us people from other parts of the world that use other currencies who _don't_ use the dollar sign except as such markup! I suppose an escape \$ or something exists to get the dollar sign if you want. USD (or AUD or whatever) is the formal way to denote the dollar anyway. Leave the dollar sign with its current semantics.

As a non dollar user, I must disagree, the problem come also from the fact
that it is difficult to determine wether or not a dolar, or double dollar
is for the beginning or the end of an expression, and wether or not it is
inline math or not. Which is a pain in many place if you want to detect
math expression.

Also from an implementation point of view, it would potentially factor a
logic we will reuse for other purposes.

Le mardi 18 juin 2013, jamadagni a écrit :

> About the dollar thing -- come on -- this is so totally dollar-centric.
> How about us people from other parts of the world that use other currencies
> who _don't_ use the dollar sign except as such markup! I suppose a way
> \dollar or something exists to get the dollar sign if you want. USD (or AUD
> or whatever) is the formal way to denote the dollar anyway.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3427#issuecomment-19625764
> .

BTW, this is going to be a tough one.  I did some more reading, and it turns out that even in the Latex community the move to a total deprecation of `$` isn't clear.  Here are some relevant threads on tex.stackechange, one [on single $](http://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/510/are-and-preferable-to-dollar-signs-for-math-mode) and a [corresponding one on $$](http://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/503/why-is-preferable-to).

It appears that deprecating `$$` wouldn't be a bad idea, but single-`$` seems to be part of latex forever.  It's also true that the readability/usability penalty of going from `$x$` to `\(x\)` is pretty severe, and it gets worse with expressions that have parens, cf. `$(x+1)$` vs. `\((x+1)\)`.  The latter reads like line-noise.

Finally, for typing mathematics-heavy text, there really is a major difference in usability between typing `$` and having to type `\(` or `\)`.

I don't have an answer I like right now...

PR #3428 significantly alleviates the problems (I wasn't aware that it was an option when we had the discussion that prompted this Issue), so perhaps sticking with the current situation is probably better than trying to force a change.

I think one missing topic here is editor support.  Using `\( \)` is easier than `$ $` to implement support like completion on latex command.  There is some "theoretical" limit on how you can help user when opening and closing characters are the same (e.g., you can't determine whether `$$` is opening double dollar or opening and closing single dollars).  `\( \)` maybe harder to type than `$ $`, but you can easily implement "quick" completion to input `\(|\)` (`|` is the cursor position) by typing `\(`.  Also, distracting opening and closing characters can have less visible color.  If you are planning to implement more editor support for markdown cell, I think `\( \)` is better.

there's a lot of good discussion on this issue, but given both some of the information which came to light, some code changes, and the fact that someone thought it'd be funny to assign this one to me and mark it for the 1.0 milestone, I propose we close it or at least punt it for 2.0
I'm +1 to close it - I don't think there's actually a feasible solution.  We can punt to 2.0 for further discussion, at least.  It's certainly not a 1.0 milestone.
Min giveth, and Min taketh away. Closing. We can always reopen later if we change our minds, and the discussion will be here to refer others to (and remind ourselved)

I _think_ @r-gaia-cs spotted a bug related to my MathJax preprocessing logic in https://github.com/swcarpentry/bc/issues/108

Has anybody else seen anything like this in the wild?  If so it, it's being caused in part by the `$` delimiter and may be further ammunition for @minrk :)
Yes, came across the same kind of things when writing some jquery code in markdown triple backticks.
Thanks, let me see if I can collect a test case from @r-gaia-cs and raise an issue here.
@ahmadia Sorry for the delay. Tomorrow I can work in a test case. Can you send me a link about the steps to follow when write the test case?

The idea of creating a test case is to create the smallest possible input that reliably triggers the bug you are observing.

In this case, a single cell with the contents:

``````
```
$x$
```
``````

Is sufficient to trigger the bug in 1.1.0.  It's obvious to me what the problem is (because I wrote this code), and that's the the current code for recognizing math blocks is searching within code spans demarcated by ``` or four-space indentation, seeing "math" in the form of dual \$s, and then failing to reconstruct the "math" after processing by MarkDown.  The @@0@@ is a side-effect of the `mathjaxutils` code when it is unable to restore math that it hid from the MarkDown parser.  My best guess for why this is happening is that the `replace_math` function is unable to recognize text that has been transformed by MarkDown's code formatter, and is therefore unable to restore any math that it modified.

The solution, then, is to fix the file: `ipython/IPython/frontend/html/notebook/static/notebook/js/mathjaxutils.js` so that it doesn't do math hiding on code blocks (demarcated either by four-space indentation or triple-tick code fences), because those are interpreted verbatim by Markdown anyway.

So instead of writing a test case, if you are up to it, you can take a crack at repairing my bug in IPython master for me :) by submitting a PR here?
@ahmadia The file to fix are `ipython/IPython/html/static/notebook/js/mathjaxutils.js`? I didn't find `ipython/IPython/frontend/html/notebook/static/notebook/js/mathjaxutils.js`.
@r-gaia-cs yes, the file have been moved near release of 1.0.

Problem "fixed" (I don't know who did it).

![ipython-mathjax-sample](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1506457/1512488/4a2b1e2a-4acc-11e3-9e8f-e9de5decb298.png)

The first cell use four spaces and the second three back-quote.

Information of the environment where I test it:

``` shell
$ cd ipython
$ git log -1
commit 210694b9dec80c8bd4585c58e145603c8144f176
Merge: 96973aa 7725c39
Author: Matthias Bussonnier <bussonniermatthias@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Nov 11 02:54:45 2013 -0800

    Merge pull request #4441 from minrk/jsversion

    add `setup.py jsversion`
$ python --version
Python 3.3.2
$ ipython --version
2.0.0-dev
$ firefox --version
Mozilla Firefox 28.0a1
```
@r-gaia-cs - of course I should have checked master to see if any of the refactoring they've done might have caught and fixed the bug.  Good to know it's no longer a bug in master.
